location.physicalLocation: Center for Historic Preservation, Middle Tennessee State University
Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University

mods.abstract: Three-story, brick and stucco church building, painted white, with steep pitched front gable roof. The north facing façade has a pediment with a large central rose (or wheel) window, flanked by two square-profiled towers. The tower facades are adorned with decorative masonry arches and circles. The entrance level features three arched doorways and stone steps.
mods.accessCondition: Reproduction permitted for non-profit educational and research purposes only. All reproductions require acknowledgement of the contributing institution.

relatedItem.abstract: Tennessee’s history between the end of the American Civil War (1865) and the end of World War II (1945) often gets ignored. Citizenship—what that has meant and how that has changed—is at the heart of this digital exploration into Tennessee history and culture “between the wars." The stories you can explore through the objects, songs, photographs, paintings, and documents of this website are often those of challenges and obstacles placed before those who pursued the rights and benefits of citizenship.

mods.note: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University
